text: Endophytes are bacteria or fungi that grow within plant transport vessels, conferring benefits such as resistance to pathogens.
The soil food web includes a complex range of microbial producers, consumers, predators, decomposers, and mutualists.
Microbial mats and biofilms are complex multispecies communities of bacteria, fungi, and other Fungi decompose lignin, a complex aromatic tree component that is challenging to digest.
Certain fungi form symbiotic associations with plant roots called mycorrhizae.
Wetland soils alternate aerated (dry) with anoxic (water-saturated) conditions.
Some fungi invade plants using haustoria, which grow into the plant cell by penetrating the cell wall and invaginating the cell membrane to avoid leakage of cytoplasm.
Some of the bacteria enter root cells and develop into nitrogen-fixing bacteroids, which gain energy from plant cell respiration but must remain anaerobic.
Some pathogens only mildly affect the plant, whereas others cause devastation.
Plant pathogens include bacteria, fungi, and viruses.
The bacteria enter the root as infection threads.
Rhizobia induce legume roots to nodulate for nitrogen fixation.
Wetland soils are among the most productive ecosystems.
Mycorrhizae transport soil nutrients among many different kinds of plants.
